Actually the theory of relativity suggests that it is impossible for any matter or information to travel faster than the speed of light. Currently, work in the area of superluminal propagation of light is being hotly debated by experts in physics. 
 
 The NEC Research institute is claiming that they have forced light to exceed 3.0x10^6 m/s by setting up and array of lasers and pulsing light through a chamber filled with cesium gas. The light emerged nanoseconds before what Einstein's equations predict. Some have questioned what this means for Einstien's theories. Researchers claim the light left the chamber before it entered. This has caused controversy since it appears to violate the laws of causality, which states that causes must always preceed there events. 
 
 I think the latter debate rests merely in the philosophical nature of physicists and there is no real basis for this claim. This result could simply be a problem with the instrumentation used to measure the data. Besides, someone had to throw the switch that started the light beam to begin with. Interesting question, though. 
 
 Be assured that Einstien's special theory of relativity remains intact, for the mean time. Scientists have defended it, by pointing to the fact that light waves have no real mass. Therefore, what was apparently measured does not violate the light barrier for matter. The answer to your question is no, matter can not travel faster than the speed of light, given what we currently know about the physical world. Is this subject to change? Always.
